exercise.rubric: Write the past tenses of these verbs.
Are these verb forms right (R) or wrong (W)? When you have checked your answers, correct any wrong verb forms.

right: paid
I paid him in cash.

question.text: The hot water pipes <item>burst</item> last night.

right: ridden
I've never ridden a horse before.
I’ve never ridden a horse before.

question.text: She’s never <item>flown</item> in a helicopter before.

right: began
The film began ten minutes ago.
forgotten
Wait! I've forgotten my keys.
Wait! I’ve forgotten my keys.
I've forgotten my keys.
I’ve forgotten my keys.

question.text: She realised she had <item>went</item> the wrong way.

right: gone
She realised she had gone the wrong way.

question.text: The horse has <item>fell</item> at the first fence.

right: fallen
The horse has fallen at the first fence.

question.text: He <item>lied</item> in his bed all morning.

right: lay
He lay in his bed all morning.

exercise.rubric: Are these spellings right (R) or wrong (W)? When you have checked your answers, correct any wrong spellings.

question.text: He was <item>hopeing</item> to leave school next year.

right: hoping
He was hoping to leave school next year.

question.text: I think he’s been <item>dying</item> his hair.

right: dyeing
I think he's been dyeing his hair.
I think he’s been dyeing his hair.

question.text: He was <item>offerring</item> to help with the gardening.

right: offering
He was offering to help with the gardening.

question.text: The police were <item>preventing</item> people from entering the building.
The horse was <item>gallopping</item> away from the field.

right: galloping
The horse was galloping away from the field.

exercise.rubric: The past ending -ed is pronounced in the same way in each word in the list except one. Find the one that is different.

feedback.desc:
44.2
In A, the others end in /d/.
In B, the others end in /t/.
In C, the others end in /ɪd/.

right: Once upon a time, a beautiful young girl lived in a forest with her grandmother.

lived
a beautiful young girl lived in a forest with her grandmother.

exercise.rubric: Here are three invitations. In what way are they different?

question.text: I <item>wonder</item> if you’d like to have dinner with me.
I <item>wondered</item> if you’d like to have dinner with me.
I <item>was wondering</item> if you’d like to have dinner with me.

exercise.answer: It’s a matter of politeness, not time. ‘Distancing’ by using past and progressive forms makes the invitations less direct and so more polite.

option: <item>Barbara’s phoned</item> today. She wants to borrow your bike.

question.text: What do you think of this way of using the present perfect?
question.input_text: Police <item>have arrested</item> 45 suspected terrorists in countrywide raids <item>last weekend</item>.

exercise.rubric: Are the following adverbs used with a simple past tense more often in American English than in British English: yes (Y) or no (N)?
Are these sentences right: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: <item>You’re looking</item> much better since your operation.
<item>You’ve been looking</item> much better since your operation.
We visit my parents every week since <item>we bought</item> the car.
We visit my parents every week since <item>we’ve bought</item> the car.
We visit my parents every week since <item>we’ve had</item> the car.

exercise.rubric: Look at these rules. Are they good: yes (Y) or no (N)?

question.text: Use the present perfect for recent actions, and the simple past for actions that took place longer ago.
Use the present perfect for finished actions that have some present importance, and the simple past for other finished actions.
Use the present perfect for unfinished actions and the simple past for finished actions.
Use the simple past, not the present perfect, when you talk about a definite time.
Use the simple past, not the present perfect, when you talk about a finished time.

exercise.rubric: Look at the sentence below. Why not ... than I have thought?
exercise.answer: We use a past tense to refer to a belief that has just been shown to be true or false.

exercise.rubric: Why is a present perfect progressive used in A and not in B?

question.text: The universe <item>has been expanding</item> steadily since its origin.
The castle <item>has looked</item> down on the city of Newlyn for the last 900 years.

exercise.answer: The simple present perfect is normally used for longer or permanent situations, but the progressive is used to talk about continuous change, even if this is permanent.

exercise.rubric: Choose the correct verb form.

question.text: I #singletouch some clothes to be cleaned. Are they ready?

exercise.rubric: Why is a past perfect used in A and not in B?

question.text: When I <item>had written</item> my letters I did some gardening.
When I <item>opened</item> the door the children ran in.

exercise.answer: To indicate a separation between the two actions.
